here in Rouen France oh we were just
talking about some things that you can
do to plan ahead when you're taking kids
on a big trip which we do a lot so yeah
here we are with all our stuff so some
of those things that we do initially is
we ask our kids where they want to go we
give them choices we pick places and
then we kind of ask their opinion on
which think they would like to do you
know maybe if we can't decide between
cities we let that mean is my trainer so
it gives them a vested interest in what
we're doing
we also talked about the trip a lot we
hype it up we have them watch maybe Bugs
Bunny when he goes to the Coliseum
before we go to Rome you know find
things movies TV shows kind of get them
excited about something before they go
and experience it
another thing we always try to do is
well if you need them book hotels with
baby beds just telling someone that you
have a one-year-old or a six-month-old
will not get you a baby bed and if you
want to get some sleep you want to get a
baby bed so do it ahead of time
another thing we do is I pack for my
whole family but I let them pick out
their clothes and you know have to kind
of give them choices again as to whether
or not you know whether appropriate
stuff and I like them to wear bright
clothes that I can spot them so I might
pick out certain things and ask them to
pick between them and again that gives
them a little more responsibility and a
little say-so and what's happening and
it really gets them involved and another
way to do that is to have them carry
their own stuff
of course we pack everything as
compactly as possible but the kids get
their own little backpack with you know
maybe a DES or some crayons or books or
whatever and having them carry that make
sure that it's light enough that they
can handle it having them be responsible
for that on the day's you're on a plane
or a train or whatever gives them again
that's an interest in what's going on
and so you know the kids are they're
happy to carry stuff around because it's
their stuff and it makes them feel a
little more important and a little more
part of the team and we've got to all
pull our own weight so it's cool for
them
another thing we try to do is to book
the bulkhead seats often they're
reserved for people in wheelchairs or
who have mobility issues but when you
get to the end you can ask ahead and if
if those are reserved sometimes when you
get to the gate you can ask then and you
may be able to get them and on European
airlines this bulkhead seats are called
the bassinet aisle and they have these
fantastic little beds that probably get
up to maybe 16 months or so depending on
size could fit into and they just slide
down on this little thing and quepos
right in a bed and they have a you know
blankets and they buckle them and that's
a lifesaver when you're you know when
you're on a 10-hour flight every little
thing helps and having a bed for your
kid is fantastic so if you can do that
book ahead and check and see if you
can't get either the bulkhead or the
bassinet aisle something else that we do
to plan ahead is we kind of go through
the rules our kids know them pretty much
by now but we try to set rules ahead of
time and talk about them because your
rules when you're traveling or are
different than the rules you have at
home you know like holding hands when
you're going through a parking lot or
crossing streets just go through those
and they'll be different for every
family I would assume but you know
you've got the basic safety things and
maybe practice them here and there
before you go so your kids get used to
and it's not all new when you get to
wherever it is that you're going we plan
a lot of do-nothing days if we could if
it were just up to Mark and I we'd
probably be in a new city over two days
but with kids you just can't do that
so we allow them a day of absolutely
nothing we may stay in a hotel room for
eight hours and watch TV in French or
Spanish or whatever and just hang out
and have family time talk read books you
know just
it's an idea that maybe you don't always
get when you're traveling because you're
trying to see so many things but it's
really helpful for us we also plan kid
activities we go to Isla Magica in
Seville or Gardaland near Milan you know
just these little cute amusement parks
are actually a lot cheaper than Disney
World and Disneyland and many of them
are very kid oriented they have a lot of
things that kids a smaller stature can
do so that's a really great thing we
also like to take our kids to zoos
there's a winch the elfin zoo on this
trip in Innsbruck Austria and it was
really cool it was all indigenous
animals we got to see something that
maybe we wouldn't see it like the San
Diego Zoo or something was just kind of

days can kind of save your sanity and
they can fix your patience and that's
number that's the last thing on our list
probably is patience you think your
patience wanes at home dear Lord it's

and you know you have train schedules
and plane schedules and all sorts of
crazy things going on and a thousand

mentally for that and you know talk to
your kids about how they can help you
and how they can have more patience to
and and that may be your biggest godsend
along with those do-nothing days and kid

it's also wonderful experience for your

you kids get to spend time with another

that setting just changes everything in

generation thrown in the mix
so those are some of our top ideas for
